title: Domenico Serafini
text:
Domenico Serafini, <a href="Order%20of%20Saint%20Benedict">O.S.B. Subl.</a> (3 August 1852 – 5 March 1918) was an Italian <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholicism%29">Cardinal</a> of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a> who served in various <a href="Diocese">pastoral</a>, <a href="Nuncio">diplomatic</a>, and <a href="Roman%20Curia">curial</a> posts, and was elevated to the <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholicism%29">cardinalate</a> in 1914.
Biography.
Domenico Serafini was born in <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, of ancient <a href="nobility">nobility</a>, to Luigi Serafini and Costanza Di Pietro. His maternal grandfather, Giovanni Di Pietro, was a <a href="College%20of%20Cardinals">consistorial</a> <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a> who, after becoming a widower, was <a href="Holy%20Orders">ordained</a> and named <a href="auditor%20%28ecclesiastical%29">auditor</a> of the <a href="Sacra%20Rota%20Romana">Roman Rota</a> by <a href="Pope%20Gregory%20XVI">Pope Gregory XVI</a>. Through his father, Domenico was related to <a href="Marchese">Marchese</a> <a href="Camillo%20Serafini">Camillo Serafini</a>, who served as the first and only <a href="Governor%20of%20the%20Vatican%20State">Governor of the Vatican State</a> (1929–1952).
Serafini entered the <a href="Order%20of%20Saint%20Benedict">Order of Saint Benedict</a> in 1871, joining the <a href="Benedictine%20Confederation">Cassinese congregation</a>. He made his <a href="Profession%20%28religious%29">profession</a> on 16 June 1874 and studied at different Benedictine houses of studies and the <a href="Pontifical%20Gregorian%20University">Pontifical Gregorian University</a>, where he obtained his <a href="Doctor%20of%20Philosophy">doctorates in philosophy</a> and <a href="Doctor%20of%20Sacred%20Theology">theology</a>. Serafini was ordained to the <a href="Priesthood%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">priesthood</a> on 21 October 1877.
From 1877 to 1892, he was a member of the Benedictine community at the <a href="abbey">abbey</a> of <a href="Subiaco%2C%20Italy">Subiaco</a>, later serving as its <a href="master%20of%20novices">master of novices</a> (1889–1891) and <a href="lector">lector</a> of <a href="theology">theology</a>. After being named prior of the <a href="Scholastica">St Scholastica</a> <a href="monastery">monastery</a>, Serafini became the general procurator of his religious order in Rome in 1892. He was elected <a href="Abbot">Abbot</a> of the two monasteries of Subiaco and <a href="Superior%20general">Abbot General</a> of the Cassinese congregation on 5 June 1896.
On 16 April 1900 Serafini was appointed <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Spoleto-Norcia">Archbishop of Spoleto</a> by <a href="Pope%20Leo%20XIII">Pope Leo XIII</a>. He received his <a href="Bishop%20%28Catholic%20Church%29">episcopal consecration</a> on the following 6 May from Cardinal <a href="Serafino%20Vannutelli">Serafino Vannutelli</a>, with Archbishops <a href="Casimiro%20Gennari">Casimiro Gennari</a> and <a href="Tommaso%20Granello">Tommaso Granello</a>, <a href="Dominican%20Order">OP</a> serving as <a href="Consecrator">co-consecrators</a>. Serafini was later named <a href="Nuncio">Apostolic Delegate</a> to <a href="Mexico">Mexico</a> on 4 January 1904, assessor of the <a href="Congregation%20for%20the%20Doctrine%20of%20the%20Faith">Supreme Congregation of the Holy Office</a> on 30 November 1911 and <a href="Titular%20bishop">Titular Bishop</a> of "Seleucia Pieria" on 2 March 1912.
<a href="Pope%20Pius%20X">Pope Pius X</a> created him <a href="Cardinal%20%28Catholicism%29">Cardinal Priest</a> of "<a href="Santa%20Cecilia%20in%20Trastevere">Santa Cecilia in Trastevere</a>" in the <a href="Papal%20consistory">consistory</a> of 25 May 1914. Some three months later, following Pius X's death, Serafini <a href="Cardinal%20electors%20in%20Papal%20conclave%2C%201914">participated</a> in the <a href="Papal%20conclave%2C%201914">papal conclave</a> to elect his successor. Serafini, supported by <a href="Gaetano%20de%20Lai">Gaetano Cardinal de Lai</a>, was the leading candidate for the <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> cardinals, who believed he would continue the teachings and policies of Pius X. His main opponent was the more <a href="Liberalism">progressive</a> <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Archdiocese%20of%20Bologna">Archbishop of Bologna</a>, <a href="Pope%20Benedict%20XV">Giacomo della Chiesa</a>, who was eventually elected on the tenth ballot—according to Francis A. Burkle-Young, the final tally was della Chiesa 38, Serafini 18, and <a href="Agostino%20Richelmy">Agostino Richelmy</a> 1—and took the name "Benedict XV".
Serafini was made <a href="Prefect">Prefect</a> of the <a href="Congregation%20for%20Institutes%20of%20Consecrated%20Life%20and%20Societies%20of%20Apostolic%20Life">Sacred Congregation of Religious</a> on 27 January 1916. Upon the death of Cardinal <a href="Girolamo%20Maria%20Gotti">Girolamo Maria Gotti</a>, Benedict XV appointed him Prefect of the <a href="Congregation%20for%20the%20Evangelization%20of%20Peoples">Sacred Congregation for the Propagation of Faith</a> on 24 March 1916, the congregation that oversees the Church's <a href="missionary">missionary</a> work.
Cardinal Serafini died in Rome at age 65. He is buried in the <a href="Campo%20Verano">Campo Verano</a>.
